info.name: about:blank / newtab / Chrome / Resource Pages
info.description: Affects about:blank / about:newtab / chrome://urls / resource://urls / view-source:urls Works well as a base for your browser and taking care of "white flashes". This turned out to be much more of a project than I had intended. All in an effort to take care of the "white flash" syndrome that seems to "affect some pages". If you are one of those people who has checked 100 times to make sure you colored every last bit of CSS but are still getting a white flash, then I suggest you read the NOTES below. Thanks to m&m_limited for help with this one.
info.additionalInfo: 2016/08/10: - finally fixed the friggin white flashes - cleaned stuff up to not affect the wrong elements in other places 2016/08/05: - added styling about:newtab to darken the menu (top right) and the opaque background (firefox only) NOTE: White Flashes on page load *** This has only been tested on Firefix *** This happens when you "right-click > Open in new tab" or "middle-click" a link and the connection to the server is slow enough to show you the actual "BROWSER" object/element (whose background is white). For some reason about:blank CSS is not applied in this case. Oddly, if you "right-click > Open in new window" this is not an issue. Maybe it's a Firefox bug, but this is a decent workaround without having to create your own full Firefox theme. Simply color the "BROWSER" element/tag. The global solution: ======================================= browser { background-color: #000000 !important; } ======================================= To be more specific, the BROWSER element/tag can be colored as part of the "chrome://" url. So the most specific CSS, at least as far as the Stylish addon is concerned, is the following: ======================================= @-moz-document url-prefix("chrome://") { browser { backgroulnd-color: #000C17 !important; } } ======================================= Any other "white flashes" are most likely missed CSS on the site you are trying to theme. Another fix is to use a dark Firefox theme that actually already colors the BROWSER element/tag. Firefox Theme: FT DeepDark ======================================= PROOF: Use this link: W3Schools URL example ======================================= 1) apply your own CSS to the BODY tag in url("about:blank") - choose a background color. Have the "BROWSER" element ready to color, but comment it out so you can see the example in action. Also make sure you are using the default Firefox theme, otherwise your current them may already color the BROWSER element. 2) use the example link from W3 above and set the "href" property in the left pane to an IP on your LAN that doesn't exist (ie. http://192.168.1.3). Then click "RUN" button to load the HTML into the right pane and test the link in right pane with "right-click > New Tab" or "middle-click". 3) After the new tab opens, activate it (click on it) and press ESC to stop the loading. The page you are looking at can only be colored with CSS by affecting the "BROWSER" element/tag, not the BODY tag of about:blank. 4) Now set your BROWSER { background-color: #blahBlah } and check the white flash page. NOTE: If you perform "right-click > new window" this issue is not present, and your about:blank BODY tag CSS will be properly applied. ======================================= You can try this on other pages too, but you'll have to be quick and activate the new tab and press ESC very quickly to actually catch the "white flash". Here's the last site i found the "white flash" problem on and it's easy-ish to catch: AutoHotkey Programming Tools Thread You can load my AutoHotkey site theme to test. Any link to one of the tools listed there should give you a white flash if you "right-click > new tab" or "middle-click" those links, and are quick enough to activate the tab after opening. Hopes this helps someone...
